text:
i also have a global team that each is working on a different product. we have a slack channel but that doesn't encourage discussion by itself. we've found it helpful to have slackbot ask us every friday "what's working for you this week?"

also we have a monthly zoom meeting where we share big wins, big challenges, and big focus for the next few weeks. they find it very helpful.

getting them in the habit of sharing with regular prompts also helps them to share more spontaneously.

elements.text:

text: Interesting idea! I feel like the first step would be determining OKRs and what "success" means for the role. X number of contributions to Y content pieces? Perhaps articulating the goal of the role will make the skillsets and core competencies a little more clear.

text: Hi all :slightly_smiling_face: Looking for a paid media specialist to co-host one of the upcoming Q&A sessions in the Slack community for advertising experts. I know all of us here are content marketers, but maybe anyone in your paid marketing team would like to share their expertise and boost your company brand awareness. I'll be happy to provide more details for those who are interested :)

Content Mavericks is expensive, but good on promotion especially.

I also bought ConversionXL to help me firm up general marketing concepts

text:
this sounds a bit more like a sales development role

if the issue is better aligning inbound & sales, sounds like that would require more of a fundamental content strategy shift whereas hiring a new role sounds more like a bandaid on a bigger issue (especially if this potential new hire would not be involved in planning content), but obviously i don't understand the whole picture there :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Webinar question: I know this is broad, but how many webinars per month do you typically see a b2b saas company hosting? I know I need to tie this back to what we're hoping to achieve (lead gen mostly) so I'm looking for a ballpark of what you all have seen/run on your own teams!

elements.text: Webinar question: I know this is broad, but how many webinars per month do you typically see a b2b saas company hosting? I know I need to tie this back to what we're hoping to achieve (lead gen mostly) so I'm looking for a ballpark of what you all have seen/run on your own teams!

text: The most we've done is 2, with 2 weeks of recruitment each, but that is rare. Usually we do one per month, or every other month if we have other events (in a normal world) or big content pieces we're pushing

elements.text: The most we've done is 2, with 2 weeks of recruitment each, but that is rare. Usually we do one per month, or every other month if we have other events (in a normal world) or big content pieces we're pushing

text: Same answer as <@U01ANAZTZTK> :point_up::skin-tone-3: no more than 2 a month. 1 if we can help it. However if one is strictly customer based then another for leads is totally fine

elements.text: Same answer as
no more than 2 a month. 1 if we can help it. However if one is strictly customer based then another for leads is totally fine

text: Our customer marketing team does do them more often on a weekly basis, but they are more like group trainings on our product than content webinars. And they aren't doing mass-recruiting every week, but have a central landing page where folks can sign up

elements.text: Our customer marketing team does do them more often on a weekly basis, but they are more like group trainings on our product than content webinars. And they aren't doing mass-recruiting every week, but have a central landing page where folks can sign up

text:
We've gone as high as 5 for lead gen webinar — but much higher than that if you include the 3x weekly webinars we offer to new customers as training (which are now largely automated).

Depends more on the distribution infrastructure than on a blanket "x per month" number

elements.text:

Depends more on the distribution infrastructure than on a blanket "x per month" number

text: Thanks Josh!

elements.text: Thanks Josh!

text: The best digital information architect practice is to leave the byline alone. Every byline should be linking to a profile/bio. Then, when people leave, all you need to do is switch the profile to read "former head of engineering" or former whatever. From a legal perspective, the company most likely owns the content (your employment/freelance contracts would confirm this), and you are within your rights to change the byline to the company name or nothing at all. But, like I said, from an ontological perspective, you're changing authorship on a published document and you're doing so to reduce information not increase it. (Not a great practice. You should work to evolve, not devolve.) Plus, your SEO may take a hit if the author has any sort of industry cred or backlinks on the piece. You're also likely pissing off the author, which then you have to deal with their ego. Leave it alone and add author bios. If you're on a CMS like WordPress or HubSpot, this is incredibly simple. (I'm also in favor of updating the content so that the issue is irrelevant, as that would evolve content.)

But, like I said, from an ontological perspective, you're changing authorship on a published document and you're doing so to reduce information not increase it. (Not a great practice. You should work to evolve, not devolve.) Plus, your SEO may take a hit if the author has any sort of industry cred or backlinks on the piece. You're also likely pissing off the author, which then you have to deal with their ego. Leave it alone and add author bios. If you're on a CMS like WordPress or HubSpot, this is incredibly simple. text: Whatever you do, don't ask them to do a content audit of your site or some other large-scale project. I've heard horrible stories of companies taking advantage of candidates during Covid because so many people are unemployed. I'm sure your friend will be respectful, butI think this project thing without any compensation is an awful trend and I'm eager for it to end.

text: Yes that is an excellent point, <@U01EJ7VE9FD>! I think they want to pull this over to the marketing team rather than sales to help more completely own the metrics on the marketing side, plus we think more could happen with optimization of content and forms to assist with that pre-qualification… but yes, I think what I’ve been gathering is that there has to be really, really good alignment with sales. Thank you!
